intro: Anthocephalus cadamba, commonly known as the Indian satinwood, is a deciduous tree native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its smooth, grayish bark and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in clusters, followed by red, fleshy berries. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is widely cultivated in gardens and traditional medicine practices.
